data.text: What Is the Best First Aid Kit for a Bikepacking Trip?
I‚Äôm preparing for a month-long trip, and looking at first aid kits. I‚Äôm not convinced I really need most of what‚Äôs in them‚Ä¶ what first aid items do you really need on a bikepacking trip?
I guess it depends partly where you're going?
data.author: Phil Metcalfe

data.text: Disinfectant, painkiller, duct tape, super glue
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: super glue?
data.author: Rebecca Shulman

data.text: for gluing wounds shut.
data.author: Simon Thompson

data.text: I agree with Phil, as well as your own typical medical needs/conditions.
data.author: Dustin Noslo

data.text: Yeah, couple of Tampax (originally designed for plugging wounds!), duct tape, Savlon, paracetamol, antihistamine tabs or cream, length of bandage, the kind that sticks to itself, but can be reused, tube of eye wash.
data.author: Jo Otteson

data.text: Cuts & abrasion first aid + bandage to immobilize until help if you‚Äôre bad off. Meds for whatever regularly ails you (differs with everyone)
data.author: Cordelia Min

data.text: I take my medication and antihistamines for alleges, I bring cream so any sores but I don‚Äôt take much else
data.author: Donald Jones

data.text: Maybe it's not what you need for you but also for others who you could help
data.author: Jon Beel

data.text: I build mine as I go. I'm pretty safe so rarely use more than banbaids.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: I just added tweezers to my kit based on another conversation.
data.author: Craig Main

data.text: I added a mini Leatherman when I had to pull cactus quills out of a friend‚Äôs leg and arm. Tweezers weren‚Äôt strong enough!
data.author: Genna DeVries

data.text: I only ride Mid-west. Cactus free.
data.author: Craig Main

data.text: 2 plasters
data.author: Alan Tucker

data.text: Length of trip and location really matter, but if it's more than one night and/or in a more remote location: Ouch-free wound cleaner, a few band aids, blister bandaids, a roll of self adhesive bandage. I carry a pair of rubber gloves because I would gladly stop and help someone else. For anything overnight I'll take benadryl, anti-diahrea medicine, tums, preferred pain medication, and an instant ice pack if I'm roughing it. If you're filtering your own water I also carry water tablets and a medication that stops vomiting. Bug spray and sunscreen, a tick removal tool and a baggy to put the tick in. Ticks are rampant where I live. Bug spray is for the evenings. First aid isn't a place I skimp, but you can totally keep it small. I don't carry whole bottles of pills, and everything I take fits in a sandwich size baggy.
data.author: Jessica Reed

data.text: exactly this - you need enough first aid gear to get you to primary help. And that‚Äôll vary depending on your trip. I‚Äôll add a snake bite bandage to this üëç
data.author: Debra Baum

data.text: So most likely you will have to deal with bug bites, saddle sores, sunburn, upset tummy, mild road rash, and other minor inconveniences but when you really need first-aid most likely you will head to the urgency / clinic. I carry regular bandaids, goo and lotions to take care of the above mention issues and pickup anything else I may need along the way. Cheers and have fun ;<)
data.author: Fred Dixon

data.text: ^^ this is a good strategy.
data.author: Lynn Haas

data.text: Anti-inflammatory (Tylenol or advil) for sore muscles, neosporin (saddle sore and cuts) hydrocortisone cream (insect bites), antihistamine tablets for overall itchiness (poison ivy, etc) large gauze pads with flex tape and large bandaids.
data.author: Mary Ann Latzgo Padglick

data.text: only thing I would add is butterfly bandaids and steri strips.
data.author: Shawn Lund

data.text: Tylenol isn‚Äôt an anti inflammatory. Advil or Motrin. Ibuprofen (aka as vitamin I)
data.author: Brian Motter

data.text: Put what you think you need in a double layer zip lock bag. If you need something that isn't in there, add it during the trip.
data.author: D Gerit Slikkers

data.text: Make your own first aid kit for you and your bike
data.author: Jason Graham

data.text: Risk vs reward & distance to medical support. PLB if beyond cell network. Ultra distance bike packers carry absolute minimum to cover wear and tear in body. On any ride, I carry a compression bandage for wounds, joint strapping or snake bite... I add chafe ointment, salt sachet to make saline, space blanket, steristrips (wound closures), asthma meds, pain killers, sterile wound pad.
data.author: Darren Hocking

data.text: You don't really need a first aid kit. I take one when I'm guiding tours with children, where I need to comfort and reassure, but not when riding solo in Europe. Think about the medicines you usually use in any month, and take those. For anything else, can you buy them easily from a pharmacy or supermarket? If so, then you probably don't need to carry them. In the worst case scenario - a nasty road accident - no first aid kit is going to help anyway.
data.author: Michael Bryant

data.text: when you come off your bike in the middle of nowhere and could do with some meds to ease the pain, wound dressings and antiseptic cream, and the nearest town with a pharmacy or supermarket is 49km in the distance, it‚Äôs great to know that you can get the stuff you need there! Even better if it‚Äôs someone else you come across that needs assistance and all you can do is point them in the right direction.
data.author: Gareth Griffith

data.text: Duct tape & whisky
data.author: Silvio Suarez

data.text: Semi truck impact...kiss it good bye
data.author: Silvio Suarez
Tom Middaugh

data.text: This all fits in an empty wipes container which fits in a water bottle holder.
data.author: Kathryn Fox

data.text: Well, it does get a little overwhelming when you need personal medication, that one cannot get over the counter SO, for that I have one of my family (could be a friend, that does not forget!) mail to general delivery, my second month of pills I need. I've found that pills can vibrate into dust on longer than 3 week tours. I try to keep it down to a minimum, a few bandaids & some gauges & some tape & crazy glue. Well I have sharp knives & I'm clumsy & have actually used it on others more than myself. Also antibiotic creme as I have a condition where small cuts/bites can become serious situation. An Epipen. The bug spray & sunscreen just seem like normal day trip items. As others have said it like so many things on a bike, its very personal. All the best.
data.author: Pat Matson

data.text: I take panadol, bandaids, a space blanket and a snakebite bandage.
data.author: Lu Cornwell

data.text:
I carry one of these. It doesn‚Äôt have everything I‚Äôd want if I packed my own kit, but it has enough to get me by should I need it. I clip it around my seat post behind me and wrap a bungee around the bottom so it‚Äôs easily accessible and plainly visible to others should they need to find it. Wouldn‚Äôt want to have it buried in a bag when you (or they) really need to get to it Life Gear 130 pc First Aid Survival Kit and Dry Bag https://www.walmart.com/ip/330414256
Life Gear 130 pc First Aid Survival Kit and Dry Bag - Walmart.com
walmart.com
data.author: Nesta Skychild
Nesta Skychild

data.text: I'd add in a tick remover, hemostatic powder (just in case) and if off road, may take the CAT I have for work.
data.author: Simon Thompson

data.text: Elastoplast for chafing. Otherwise for a minor problem I‚Äôll hold on till I come to a pharmacy. Major ailment I‚Äôm going home/hospital/mortuary. I‚Äôm a doctor
data.author: Dan Noble

data.text: Band aids and first aid cream.
data.author: John Goldman

data.text: The most likely injury is big grazes ie road rash. I normally carry large gauzes, the means to attach them (ie tape) and antiseptic. I typically only carry enough supplies to get me to the nearest store, where I can purchase what I might need, which obviously depends on where I am.
data.author: Shirley Acreman

data.text: I just got back from RAGBRAI, a week-long trip. My kit (I used all of these): alcohol wipes, big bandages (like for covering road rash), roll of gauze, medium waterproof bandages (like for covering a relatively small cut for several days),tape (I have sensitive skin, so I use blue tape), pair of scissors, nail clippers, antibiotic ointment, Vaseline, Benadryl, ibuprofen, Tylenol, hydrocortisone ointment, chemical ice pack I used everything during this trip, which included several bike gear cuts (my mom and I) and one crash (my 11y daughter). My daughter‚Äôs crash wasn‚Äôt too bad, just some bruises and scrapes over her ribs from her handlebars, and a little road rash. The only thing I bright that we didn‚Äôt use all week was a nail file.
data.author: Elizabeth Wiczer
